tit.cmt: OK - but I think it might need a note on pronunciation seeing as how it's spelt the same as the English word 'shake'

sen.j: 社家（しゃけ）とは、日本の身分のひとつである。
sen.e: Shake is one of Japanese social classes.
Shake is a Japanese social class.
Shake is a Japanese social class.

sen.j: 社家とは、代々特定神社の神職を世襲してきた家（氏族）のことである。
sen.e: Shake is a family (clan) that has succeeded Shinto priesthood for a certain shrine by heredity for generations.
Shake is a family (clan) that has had hereditary Shinto priesthood for generations.
Shake is a family (clan) that has had hereditary Shinto priesthood for generations.

sen.j: 律令制の崩壊とともに、神職が自分の子にその職を継がせる例が多くなった。
sen.e: Along with collapse of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code), more Shinto priests had their son succeed their position.
With the collapse of the Ritsuryo system (a legal and administrative system based on Confucianism and Chinese law), more and more Shinto priests passed their position on to their sons.
With the collapse of the Ritsuryo system (a legal and administrative system based on Confucianism and Chinese law), more and more Shinto priests passed their position on to their sons.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）の太政官布告により神職の世襲は、色々と弊害があるとして廃止された。
sen.e: With the edict of Dajokan (Grand Council of state) in 1871, the heredity of Shinto priesthood was abolished because of various negative effects.
In 1871, because of various negative effects, heredity priesthood was abolished by an edict from the Dajokan (Grand Council of State).
In 1871, because of various negative effects, heredity priesthood was abolished by an edict from the Dajokan (Grand Council of State).

sen.j: しかし、第二次大戦後、神社や神職が政府の管理から離れたことにより、かつて社家であった家や、明治以降神職となった者の子孫が神職を世襲する例が増加した。
sen.e: However, families which used to be Shake or the descendants of those who became Shinto priests after the Meiji Period increasingly succeeded Shinto priesthood by heredity, since shrines and Shinto priesthood were not controlled by the government any more after the World War II.

However, when shrines and the priesthood were removed from government control after World War II, former Shake families and the descendants of those who became Shinto priests after the Meiji Period increasingly passed on their positions through inheritance.

However, when shrines and the priesthood were removed from government control after World War II, former Shake families and the descendants of those who became Shinto priests after the Meiji period increasingly passed on their positions through inheritance.

sen.j: 現在ではそのような家のことも社家と呼んでいる。
sen.e: Today, such families are also called Shake.
Today, such families are also called Shake.
Today, such families are also called Shake.

sen.j: 歴史的に著名な社家には以下のようなものがある。
sen.e: Historically well-known Shake are listed below.
Historically well-known Shake are listed below.

sen.cmt: 登録の中にChief mournerとあるのですが、これはいわゆる喪主だと思うので、不採用。Tangorin参照。

sen.e: Naiku-shishoku (a priest for the inner shrine)
Naiku-shishoku (a priest for the inner shrine)
Geku-shishoku (a priest for the outer shrine)
Geku-shishoku (a priest for the outer shrine)

sen.j: 鹿島神宮・香取神宮・春日大社
sen.e: Kashima-jingu Shrine, Katori-jingu Shrine and Kasuga Taisha Shrine
Kashima-jingu Shrine, Katori-jingu Shrine and Kasuga Taisha Shrine
Kashima-jingu Shrine, Katori-jingu Shrine and Kasuga Taisha Shrine
-- The Nakatomi clan and the Onakatomi clan
The Nakatomi clan and the Onakatomi clan
The Nakatomi clan and the Onakatomi clan

sen.j: -- 到津氏・宮成氏（宇佐国造）
sen.e: -- The Itozu clan and the Miyanari clan (Usanokuni no Miyatsuko)
The Itozu clan and the Miyanari clan (Usanokuni no Miyatsuko)
The Itozu clan and the Miyanari clan (Usanokuni no Miyatsuko)

sen.j: -- 千家氏・北島氏（出雲国造）
sen.e: -- The Senge clan and the Kitajima clan (Izumonokuni no Miyatsuko)
The Senge clan and the Kitajima clan (Izumonokuni no Miyatsuko)
The Senge clan and the Kitajima clan (Izumonokuni no Miyatsuko)

sen.j: 賀茂別雷神社（上賀茂神社）・賀茂御祖神社（下鴨神社）
sen.e: Kamowakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) and Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja Shrine)
Kamowakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) and Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja Shrine)
Kamowakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) and Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja Shrine)
-- The Juge clan and the Shogenji clan
The Juge clan and the Shogenji clan
The Juge clan and the Shogenji clan

sen.j: -- 諏訪氏・金刺氏・洩矢神
sen.e: -- The Suwa clan, the Kanasashi clan and the Moriya clan
sen.cmt: 洩矢神はリンク先の単語で、サイト上の「守矢氏」を訳出。
sen.e: The Suwa clan, the Kanasashi clan and the Moriya clan
The Suwa clan, the Kanasashi clan and the Moriya clan

sen.j: 社家は奉職する神社の近くに家を構えることが多く、社家の家が集まった所は「社家町（しゃけまち）」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Shake usually had a house near the shrine that they served, and the districts where there were several Shake families were called 'Shake-machi.'
Shake usually had a house near the shrine that they served, and districts where several Shake families lived were called 'Shake-machi.'
Shake usually had a house near the shrine that they served, and districts where several Shake families lived were called 'Shake-machi.'

sen.j: 現代日本において「社家町」「社家」という地名は各地にあり、その多くはかつて社家町があった場所である。
sen.e: In the modern-day Japan, there are place-names called 'Shake-machi' or 'Shake' all over the country, most of which are the district where there used to be Shake-machi.
In modern-day Japan, 'Shake-machi' and 'Shake' are used in many place names all over country, most of which are districts where there used to be Shake-machi.
In modern-day Japan, 'Shake-machi' and 'Shake' are used in many place names all over country, most of which are districts where there used to be Shake-machi.

sen.j: 社家町として有名な地区

tit.j: 奈良市高畑（たかばたけ）町界隈
出雲市真名井社家通り
